paper.title: P1GPT: A Multi-Agent LLM Workflow Module for Multi-Modal Financial Information Analysis

executive_summary: P1GPT proposes a five-layer multi-agent LLM workflow that fuses technical, fundamental, and news signals into auditable buy/sell/hold decisions. The architecture is implementation-relevant for structured orchestration and traceability, but empirical claims are not sufficient for production trading because evaluation scope is narrow and execution assumptions are simplified.
problem_statement: How to design a scalable, explainable multi-agent LLM system that can integrate heterogeneous financial modalities into actionable trading decisions.
methodology_summary: The framework processes data through Input, Planning, Analysis, Integration, and Action Decision layers. Domain-specialized and supporting agents produce standardized reports that are fused via rule-based and LLM-based synthesis with optional conflict-resolution loops. Evaluation uses backtests on AAPL/GOOGL/TSLA (Feb-Sep 2025) against rule-based baselines under frictionless single-position execution assumptions.

key_findings.finding: The layered architecture is clear enough to support modular implementation with auditable stage boundaries.
Reported returns and risk-adjusted metrics outperform selected rule-based baselines for all three tested assets.
Case studies provide interpretable decision transitions via cross-agent reasoning narratives.
Evaluation realism is limited by short horizon, small asset set, and omission of transaction costs.

novelty_claims.claim: First end-to-end multi-agent LLM workflow tailored to multi-modal financial analysis
novelty_claims.notes: The layered design is concrete, but related multi-agent financial frameworks already exist and are acknowledged in Section 2.

novelty_claims.claim: Structured communication and standardized reporting improve interpretability and reliability
novelty_claims.notes: The architecture and case reports align with this claim, though quantitative reliability gains are not isolated via ablation.
Table 2 shows strong results, but external validity is constrained by dataset scope and simplified execution assumptions.

risk_assessment.detail: Three stocks and one short market window are insufficient to establish robust generalization.
No transaction costs, slippage, or portfolio constraints likely inflate apparent performance.
No ablation/statistical tests isolate whether layered multi-agent design is the true cause of gains.
Conflict-resolution loops can introduce oscillatory behavior without strict arbitration policies.
Narrative rationales alone are insufficient for full compliance-grade reproducibility without immutable run artifacts.

implementation_implications: Adopt the five-layer orchestration contract and standardized agent report schema.
Persist structured intermediate artifacts for deterministic replay and audit.
Add conflict-handling policies and disagreement diagnostics in integration.
Require cost-aware and portfolio-aware backtest gates before promotion.
Use paper-trading plus human approval before any live-capital activation.

citations.claim: Defines end-to-end workflow, structured protocol, and performance claims.
Introduces five-layer architecture and data/control flow.
Describes multi-modal ingestion and normalization pipeline.
Explains conflict handling and iterative refinement.
Defines assets, period, baselines, and metrics.
States execution assumptions including no transaction costs and single-position policy.
Reports higher CR/AR/SR results for P1GPT on tested assets.
Provides case-level Sell-to-Buy rationale transition for AAPL.
Acknowledges missing transaction costs, portfolio interactions, and limited window.
